2020-06-12T17:41:30.000Z: The best way for claimants to find information on their claim is to log into their account online. DETR continues to work on refining guidance, and working closely with IT staff to explore technology solutions. I want to thank DETR for their continued hard work to help Nevadans.
2020-06-12T17:41:29.000Z: Also, thanks to the implementation of a cloud based phone system, additional staff, & the resolution of issues with phone service providers, DETR's standard UI phone lines are staying open for longer periods of time resulting in more calls getting through to claims staff.
2020-06-12T17:41:27.000Z: DETR's PUA vendor is actively recruiting, hiring and training call center representatives and adjudicators to assist with the volume of claims they are currently receiving.
2020-06-12T17:41:25.000Z: Additionally, DETR has been made aware of robocallers that have been jamming phone lines. DETR and the vendor have deployed technology to prevent robocallers with the hope that this allows many more calls to be connected to a customer service representative.
2020-06-12T17:41:23.000Z: Many individuals and organizations have reached out with concerns about both PUA and standard UI fraud - If you suspect fraud, please file a report with DETR's fraud unit by visiting http:// Detr.nv.gov
2020-06-12T17:41:21.000Z: Many of the PUA claims have been identified as potentially fraudulent. DETR has implemented measures to proactively freeze payment and investigate both known and suspected fraud. Nevada is coordinating with other states and entities to stop fraudulent claims prior to payment.
2020-06-12T17:41:19.000Z: Adjudicating wages on the back end of a claim is not an option in standard UI, but the CARES Act does allow for this flexibility in PUA and the department is utilizing this option.
2020-06-12T17:41:17.000Z: According to the CARES Act, DETR must ensure that PUA claimants are not eligible for standard UI before making PUA payments. Once DETR has determined that a claimant is eligible for PUA payment, it pays on the self-attested wages and will adjudicate the precise wages after.
2020-06-12T17:41:15.000Z: Of the remaining eligible unpaid PUA claims many have eligibility issues that are being resolved and payments are processed daily. DETR is finding ways to batch process these claims and release payment to as many people as possible.
2020-06-12T17:41:13.000Z: Of the more than 80,000 eligible PUA claims, DETR has paid 47,582 individual claims for a total $355.8 million in PUA and PUA Federal Pandemic Unemployment Compensation dollars.
2020-06-12T17:41:11.000Z: DETR has a glossary of terms to help those filing for PUA found at http:// detr.nv.gov/PUA . As of today, there have been 116,996 initial  claims and 1,058,447 claims weeks filed. An estimated 35,600 claimants have not filed weekly claims - around 30 percent.
2020-06-12T17:41:09.000Z: Some of those claims filed for standard UI are not eligible -  some did not file a claim for the week and others are pending because federal law requires DETR adjudicate the claim. So far, DETR has paid out over $3 billion in unemployment benefits.
2020-06-12T17:41:07.000Z: As of May 30, 529,646 total claims have been filed for standard UI. Of those eligible filers who filed weekly claims - 276,418, or 88% of eligible claims were successfully paid.

2020-05-27T04:33:15.000Z: We cannot do this without each of you accepting the personal responsibility to follow the social distancing guidelines in professional and personal decisions.
2020-05-27T04:33:07.000Z: As always, I encourage Nevadans to stay vigilant and protect themselves against this virus.  Our goal is to prevent a surge in cases that our health care system cannot handle.
2020-05-27T04:32:56.000Z: The Board will issue an industry notice tomorrow setting forth requirements for the resumption of gaming operations in the State of Nevada.
2020-05-27T04:32:47.000Z: I know the Gaming Control Board remains resolute in ensuring that gaming operations in this State do not compromise the health and safety of Nevadans, our employees and our visitors.
2020-05-27T04:32:30.000Z: It is critical to put the health & safety of employees, residents & visitors first through proactive measures, coupled with the Health & Safety Policies issued by the Gaming Control Board. This is what will help ensure that Nevada can safely reopen its gaming industry on June 4.
2020-05-27T04:32:04.000Z: The Board was briefed on how these various entities have worked with the gaming industry to ensure that there is a comprehensive plan in place to respond to and mitigate the effects of positive cases of COVID-19 that present themselves in the State's resort corridors.
2020-05-27T04:31:55.000Z: I want to thank Chairwoman Sandra Douglass Morgan and the Board for holding its informational workshop this morning, during which the Board received testimony from the state's COVID-19 Response Director, public health experts, and leaders of our emergency response departments.
2020-05-27T04:31:34.000Z: Last week, I set a target reopening date of Thursday, June 4, for our gaming industry. Based on the meeting today and the positive trends in our data, I have informed the Chair of the Gaming Control Board that I feel confident in the June 4th target date.
2020-05-27T04:31:24.000Z: Places of worship may reopen their doors for gatherings with a maximum of 50 people attending a service at a time and strict social distancing of at least six feet. This aligns with our new guidance on all public and private gatherings.
2020-05-27T04:31:02.000Z: I strongly urge places of worship continue to provide online or virtual services as much as possible to protect those they serve, especially those who are among our vulnerable populations.
2020-05-27T04:30:53.000Z: Our medical experts advise that bringing together people from different households in a confined space for extended periods of time greatly increases the likelihood of spreading COVID-19.
2020-05-27T04:30:31.000Z:
For so many Nevadans, restricting faith-based gatherings has been especially difficult.     
Across the country we have seen houses of worship become hotspots for COVID-19 transmission.
2020-05-27T04:30:14.000Z: Again, specific industry guidance for all these industries is being finalized with my Office and the Local Empowerment Advisory Panel and will be posted online and distributed this week, but I wanted to make this announcement to allow our Nevada businesses to make preparations.
2020-05-27T04:29:52.000Z: We've asked for recommendations, from local youth sports associations, the LEAP and national organizations. There are a lot of considerations at play here and for our youth, we want to make sure we have a strong, safe plan in place.
2020-05-27T04:29:45.000Z: Finally, we anticipate that youth sports and recreation will be able to open at some point in Phase 2. I know youth sports are important.
2020-05-27T04:29:33.000Z: For those that don't fall within the jurisdiction of the Nevada Athletic Commission or the Gaming Control Board, they will be approved by the Nevada Department of Business & Industry
2020-05-27T04:29:21.000Z: For example, the Gaming Control Board will approve these events on gaming properties, and the Nevada Athletic Commission will approve these events for any athletic competitions that it regulates.
2020-05-27T04:29:10.000Z: To hold a closed or spectator-less event,  an Event Operator shall submit an Operation Plan to the appropriate state authority with jurisdiction over the event.
2020-05-27T04:28:47.000Z: This may include sporting events, concerts, theater performances, or other entertainment type events.  There will be also be protocols for other spectator less events that won't be filmed or broadcasted.
2020-05-27T04:28:38.000Z: In Phase 2, events with live performances and live performers will not be allowed WITH spectators.  However, certain events will be allowed under specific restrictions for the purpose of broadcasting or live streaming - but they will NOT include a live audience or any spectators.
2020-05-27T04:28:26.000Z: There will be similar restrictions for outdoor venues like mini golf and amusement parks.
2020-05-27T04:28:15.000Z: Each individual retail store within an indoor mall will be subject to the same 50% capacity mandate and social distancing requirements. Food courts must adhere to the same restrictions as restaurants.
2020-05-27T04:28:06.000Z: Indoor venues, like movie theaters, bowling alleys & indoor malls may reopen, again with occupancy restrictions and must allow for six feet of social distancing. Malls must prohibit areas where people congregate, including restricting seating or benches in hallways or open areas
2020-05-27T04:27:42.000Z: Museums, art galleries, zoos and aquariums may reopen in Phase 2, at no more than 50 percent of capacity and must maintain at least six feet of social distancing. Interactive and hands-on exhibits must remain closed during this phase.
2020-05-27T04:27:31.000Z: Water parks will also be able to reopen, at 50 percent capacity with strict social distancing requirements.
2020-05-27T04:27:20.000Z: Aquatic facilities and swimming pools may reopen. During Phase 2, locker rooms will not be allow to reopen and these facilities will be limited to 50 percent of capacity. Face coverings should NOT be worn in the water.
2020-05-27T04:27:04.000Z: Body art and piercing establishments may reopen in Phase 2, with strict guidelines and by appointment only. During Phase 2, no body art or piercings may be done around the nose or mouth so that face coverings can be worn at all times.
2020-05-27T04:26:54.000Z: Massage services may also reopen under similar conditions, including by appointment only.  Face coverings must be worn at all times by employees, including the masseuse
2020-05-27T04:26:44.000Z: Day and overnight spas may reopen to offer these services but may NOT open steam rooms, saunas, hot tubs or other communal facilities.
2020-05-27T04:26:32.000Z:
Salons and/or other businesses that provide aesthetic or other skin services may open under strict protocols and guidelines as recommended by LEAP and the Cosmetology Board.  

These include facials, hair removal, tanning, eyelash services, eyebrow threading, and other services.
2020-05-27T04:26:06.000Z: Patrons will NOT be allowed to walk up and order at the bars, but they may sit and be served at a bar top if appropriately distanced from one another - 6 feet apart. No congregating.
2020-05-27T04:25:58.000Z: All of the same restrictions on restaurants and food establishments are continued in Phase 2, but bar areas in restaurants may reopen, and bars and taverns that DO NOT serve food may reopen under the same restrictions - 50% maximum capacity and strict social distancing.
2020-05-27T04:25:42.000Z: Larger gyms are capped at 50% of occupancy per fire code and must also adhere to the strict social distancing requirements. Additionally, equipment must be regulated to ensure six feet of social distancing.
2020-05-27T04:25:21.000Z: Gyms, fitness facilities and other studios may reopen in Phase 2.  If a smaller gym or studio can only accommodate 10 or less people, they may only do so if they can adhere to the social distancing requirements and keep 6 feet of distance between all individuals.
2020-05-27T04:24:54.000Z: In Phase 2, state offices may begin to resume some services where necessary, although online services are still available and encouraged.  My office is finalizing plans with our agency directors on offices to reopen initially and will be making announcements on a rolling basis.
2020-05-27T04:24:24.000Z: During Phase 2, additional businesses and entities will be able to open. More specific guidance will be issued by my office and the Local Empowerment Advisory Panel (LEAP) but I wanted to go over the toplines of this new directive, which will be issued and signed tomorrow.
2020-05-27T04:23:59.000Z: All businesses opened in Phase 1 must maintain all the same restrictions and guidelines as we continue to evaluate the impact and slowly lift restrictions on other activities.
2020-05-27T04:23:26.000Z:
Businesses that remain closed in Phase 2 include: 

Adult entertainment establishments 

Brothels  

Nightclubs and day clubs  

Live sporting event venues and live performance venues WITH spectators.
2020-05-27T04:23:15.000Z: There are some businesses that will remain closed in Phase 2. Similar to Phase 1, Phase 2 will last 2-3 weeks as we monitor the data and evaluate trends and progress.

2020-05-01T00:25:47.000Z: I know my remarks have been long, but I find it important to summarize: the next 15 days will be our active transition to a safe and methodical reopening of our economy.
2020-05-01T00:22:18.000Z: There's much more info in the Nevada United: Roadmap to Recovery Plan, which can be found online. This plan provides more information on what our phases will look like, including potential duration, goals and expectations - all that will lead us to our eventual new normal.
2020-05-01T00:22:17.000Z: After each phase of reopenings, state public health officials will review the numbers of new COVID-19 daily case counts, hospitalizations, & deaths carefully. 2020-05-01T00:19:11.000Z: I am happy to announce the formation of the Local Empowerment Advisory Panel, or "LEAP," a group of Nevada stakeholders who will serve as a resource for counties as they work through the requirements to reopen and share best practices and guidelines for local communities.
2020-05-01T00:19:10.000Z: Our response efforts should reflect our regional differences, while still operating under our shared, statewide goal of keeping Nevadans safe and restarting our economy.
2020-05-01T00:16:16.000Z: If you've lost the live feed, please follow along on my YouTube page: Governor Sisolak Live Stream youtube.com
2020-05-01T00:15:15.000Z: We will consider the gradual reopening of dine-in restaurants and personal care services, but with strict guidelines to protect the health and safety of the workers and the customers.  These will be thoroughly reviewed to ensure Nevadans can remain safe.
2020-05-01T00:15:14.000Z: The virus remains among us, and people infected with the virus will spread it to others when strong social distancing measures are not in use. It's critical that Nevadans continue wearing improvised face coverings, or "non-medical" masks, whenever they leave their home.
2020-05-01T00:15:13.000Z: In the next couple of weeks, our focus will be on meeting the criteria & moving into Phase 1 on or before May 15. I'd like to walk through an overview of what you can expect in Phase 1, or as we will call it, our "Battle Born Beginning."

2020-05-01T00:08:53.000Z: Third, we want to have the expanded ability for healthcare providers to administer tests for symptomatic patients and sufficient laboratory testing capacity to process COVID-19 testing samples.

2020-05-01T00:10:14.000Z: Fourth, we need sufficient public health workforce capacity in health departments to conduct case contact tracing. These efforts continue to ramp up to scale. We feel very positive & are exploring many ways to expand this workforce & be ready for Phase 1.

2020-04-09T01:33:22.000Z:
(5) licensed barbers & stylists are prohibited from offering in-home beauty services other than to those in household;

Barbers & hair stylists are not essential. Going to someone's home doesn't change that fact. I haven't had a haircut in over 6 weeks. I've adjusted. So can you.
2020-04-09T01:33:21.000Z:
(3) operating businesses must provide adequate protections for their workers & adopt sanitation protocols that minimize risk of spread;

This is a common-sense measure to ensure businesses are operating safely.
2020-04-09T01:33:20.000Z:
We know that essential businesses can do better, too.

And while I encourage outdoor activity as much as possible, some activities have unnecessarily become high-risk due to people circumventing the intent of our social distancing directives.
2020-04-09T01:33:19.000Z: There are lessons we've learned from other states-some have allowed religious services to continue without restriction, which has been followed by a spike in new infections. We can't let that happen in NV. And our businesses can do a better implementing social distancing.
2020-04-09T01:33:18.000Z: From the start, I've been clear about my goal: mitigate the spread of #COVID19 to save lives & protect our health care system from being overwhelmed, which could lead to disastrous results.
